questions.text: A 45 y/o woman undergoes a superficial parotidectomy for a pleomorphic adenoma. Which of the following is a known complication associated with this condition or its treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent facial nerve paralysis is common after parotidectomy.

options.label: B
options.text: Pleomorphic adenomas rarely recur after surgical excision.

options.label: C
options.text: Radiotherapy for pleomorphic adenoma is risk-free and only used as a primary treatment.

options.label: D
options.text: Frey’s syndrome is characterized by sweating and flushing in the preauricular area during meals.

questions.correct_answer: D. Frey’s syndrome is characterized by sweating and flushing in the preauricular area during meals.

questions.text: A 28-y/o male presents with a painless, soft swelling in the submandibular region that has been gradually enlarging over the past 2 months. On examination, the swelling is dumbbell-shaped, fluctuant, and bidigitally palpable. The overlying mucosa appears thick with a bluish hue. Fine needle aspiration yields a viscous, "egg white-like" fluid with high amylase content, confirming the diagnosis. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Incision and drainage of the cyst

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical excision of the ranula and involved sublingual gland

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical excision of the ranula and involved sublingual gland
questions.explanation:
Plunging Ranula

Definition
  • When a ranula extends into the submandibular region through the deeper part of the posterior margin of the mylohyoid muscle it is called a plunging ranula.

Key Features
  • Painless, soft, fluctuant dumbbell-shaped swelling in the submandibular region or sublingual area. It is bidigitally palpable.
  • May have a bluish hue and thick overlying mucosa.
  • Often presents with both oral and cervical components.
  • Typically occurs in the third decade of life.

Diagnosis
  • Based on history, clinical features, and imaging.
  • Fine needle aspiration yields a viscous, "egg white-like" fluid with high amylase content.
  • Ultrasonography or CT shows a well-circumscribed cystic mass extending through the mylohyoid muscle.

Treatment
  • Surgical excision of the ranula and involved sublingual gland is the definitive treatment.
  • Recurrence is possible if the sublingual gland is not completely removed.

questions.text: A 16 y/o female has a painless, soft, fluctuant swelling in the anterior floor of her mouth that has increased in size over a few weeks. There is no history of trauma or infection. What is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ranula

Definition

Ranulas are a type of extravasation mucocele, caused by the rupture of the main duct or obstructed acini of the sublingual gland. They appear as bluish swellings on the floor of the mouth and resemble the belly of a frog.

Location
  • Commonly found in the anterior floor of the mouth.
  • When it extends through the mylohyoid muscle, it presents as a submental swelling known as a "plunging ranula."

Symptoms

Typically soft, fluctuant, and painless unless infected.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed through Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
  • Ultrasound
  • Aspiration of thick sticky saliva differentiates it from a lymphangioma.

Treatment
  • Removal of the sublingual gland is preferred.
  • Incision, drainage, and marsupialization have low success rates. Although marsupialization is often adequate, it has a higher recurrence rate compared to sublingual gland excision.
  • OK-432 injection
  • Botulinum toxin injections

questions.text: A 52 y/o male has recurrent pain and swelling in the left lower jaw, worsening over several months. On examination, there is a significant swelling of the right submandibular gland, but no palpable stone. A CT scan shows an 8 mm stone deep within the submandibular gland, inaccessible by sialendoscopy. What is the best next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Sialolithiasis

Definition

Formation of salivary gland stones within the gland ducts

Commonly Affected Age

30 to 60 years

Commonly Affected Gland

Submandibular gland (85%), due to its ascending duct course and the mucinous, viscous saliva it produces, leads to stagnation and stone formation.

Risk Factors
  • Duct abnormalities
  • Inflammation
  • Increased calcium content in saliva
  • Chronic dehydration
  • Medications causing decreased salivary flow

Clinical Features

Cyclical postprandial swelling, dryness, asymmetrical gland enlargement, palpable stone, possible abscess formation.

Submandibular Swelling

Diagnostic Methods
  • Conventional Radiographs: Initial diagnostic test, but may miss small stones.
  • CT Scanning, USG, Magnetic Resonance Sialogram: More sensitive, especially for small stones.
  • Sialography: Gold standard; involves dye injection for diagnosis and potential therapeutic use.
  • Sialendoscopy: Direct visualization and removal of stones, safer than open surgery.

CT- Wharton’s duct Sialolithiasis

Treatment Options
  • Small Distal Stones (<5 mm): Endoscopic removal (Option A ruled out)
  • Large Distal Stones (>5 mm): Duct slitting (Option B ruled out)
  • Impacted Stones: Transoral route
  • Intraparenchymal Stones (5–7 mm): Endoscopic extraction
  • Large Stones (7-10 mm): May require transoral slitting or external shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL)
  • Hilar Stones: Endoscopic removal
  • Gland Removal: Last resort if other treatments fail (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman is undergoing surgery for the removal of a submandibular gland mass. Postoperatively, she complains of numbness and a burning sensation of her tongue. Which nerve is most likely to have been injured during the procedure?

A 60 y/o man with a diagnosis of adenoid cystic carcinoma has undergone surgical resection of a tumour located in the palate. Postoperative imaging reveals no residual tumour but shows the involvement of regional lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate additional treatment for this patient?

A 60 y/o man presents with a slow-growing, painless mass in the submandibular region. O/E, the mass is firm and non-tender and biopsy reveals a tumor with a combination of tubular and solid histological patterns. Imaging shows perineural invasion extending towards the base of the skull. Which histopathological type in this carcinoma is associated with the worst prognosis?
Which immunohistochemical marker helps to distinguish acinic cell carcinoma from secretory carcinoma?

A 45 y/o female has a firm, enlarging swelling below her left ear for 6 months. O/E, the swelling is hard and nodular, with no signs of facial nerve involvement. FNAC shows malignant cells, and imaging reveals a tumour in both lobes of the parotid gland with no distant metastases. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following statements about Warthin's tumour and its diagnostic features is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is best identified on imaging by its hypoechoic appearance and confirmed with FNAC.

options.label: B
options.text: A Tc99 pertechnetate scan showing a "hotspot" is indicative of Warthin's tumour.

options.label: D
options.text: Warthin's tumour generally exhibits low uptake on Tc99 pertechnetate scans

questions.correct_answer: B. A Tc99 pertechnetate scan showing a "hotspot" is indicative of Warthin's tumour.

questions.text: Which of the following salivary glands secretes saliva through Stensen’s duct?
questions.explanation:
Gland

Duct

Parotid gland

Stensen’s Duct

Submandibular gland

Wharton’s Duct

Sublingual gland

Ducts of Rivinus

Minor salivary glands

Numerous small ducts

questions.text: A 35 y/o female has a slowly enlarging, painless, well-defined mass in the left parotid gland, present for two years. O/E there is no facial nerve involvement. Ultrasound shows a well-lobulated, hypoechoic lesion, and FNAC suggests a benign neoplasm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical excision with a margin of normal tissue

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical excision with a margin of normal tissue

questions.text: A 50 y/o female with swelling and pus discharge from the left cheek for two weeks, worsening with eating, recently had a superficial parotidectomy. Examination reveals a small external opening at the parotid region with saliva-like discharge. What is the best initial management?
questions.correct_answer: D. Anticholinergic therapy with hyoscine bromide

questions.text: A 60 y/o male undergoes a parotidectomy for a benign tumour located in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland. On the second postoperative day, he notices sweating and flushing in the area just in front of his ear when he eats. The patient also reports mild numbness of the earlobe. Which of the following nerves is most commonly affected?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

Temporary Facial Palsy
  • Mostly the lower branches of the facial nerve - the marginal mandibular nerve.
  • Most patients recover over time.

Infection

  • Rare, as parotidectomy is a clean procedure.
  • Aseptic precautions and timely drain removal reduce the risk.

Hematoma Formation
  • Uncommon.
  • Careful intraoperative hemostasis can prevent it.
  • Larger hematomas may indicate a bleeding disorder and require management.

Sialocele Formation

  • Occurs if the main ductal system is exposed.
  • Preventable with subcapsular dissection.
  • Treatment: Anticholinergics, aspiration, and pressure dressings.

Retromandibular area hollowing
  • Can occur post-surgery
  • Reduced by placing autologous fat grafts during the surgery.

Frey’s Syndrome
  • Also known as gustatory sweating;
  • Caused by the cross-innervation of sweat glands by regenerating nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve. (Option B)
  • For mild cases: Give antiperspirants;
  • Severe cases: Botulinum toxin injections or tympanic neurectomy.

Permanent Facial Nerve Weakness
  • D/t transection of the facial nerve during the surgery. (Option A ruled out)

Facial Numbness
  • Permanent numbness of the earlobe,
  • D/t transection of the great auricular nerve during the surgery. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 45 y/o patient presents with a parotid gland tumour located deep to the facial nerve. The tumour has been identified as malignant and has extended beyond the parotid gland. Given these findings, which surgical approach is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Extracapsular Dissection

  • Tumor removed.
  • No facial nerve dissection.
  • ↓ Chances of temporary facial palsy.

Adequate Parotidectomy (Option D ruled out)
  • Tumor removal along with some healthy tissue.
  • Aimed to preserve the gland.
  • Challenging if the tumour is near the facial nerve.

Superficial Parotidectomy (Option C ruled out)
  • Performed when the tumour is located lateral to the facial nerve.

Total Parotidectomy

Indicated when the tumour is deep to the facial nerve.

Total Conservative Parotidectomy (Option B ruled out)

Involves removing both superficial and deep lobes while preserving the facial nerves. Used for tumours crossing the facial nerve plane.

Radical Parotidectomy

Complete removal of the parotid gland, including any involved facial nerve branches, for malignant tumours extending beyond the gland.

questions.text: A 62 y/o woman presents with a recurrent adenoid cystic carcinoma of the submandibular gland. The tumour has been surgically resected twice before, and each time, the pathology report showed perineural invasion. What is the most appropriate next step in managing her condition?

A 45 y/o woman presents with a progressively enlarging mass in her right parotid gland. The mass is non-tender and has been present for 6 months. An ultrasound revealed a well-defined hypoechoic lesion with no evidence of calcification or increased vascularity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
Which is the most common salivary gland tumour found in infants and young children?
questions.explanation:
Salivary gland tumors

The most common benign tumour

Pleomorphic adenoma

The most common benign tumour of infants and young children

Hemangioma

The most common malignant tumour

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

The most common malignant tumour in children and young adults

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

The most common malignant tumour of Minor salivary glands

Adenoid cystic carcinoma

questions.text: A 50 y/o male presents with a swelling in his parotid gland, and a biopsy reveals a Warthin's tumour. Which of the following is most likely a contributing risk factor for this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic inflammation of the salivary glands
